Is this the far-fam'd spot of earth,</br>Which gave immortal Milton birth?</br>Is this the soil where Hampden bled,</br>And Hampden's tyrant lost his head?</br>Is this the insulated ground</br>For men of fearless truth renown'd,</br>For men who felt as men should feel,</br>And nobly grasp'd th' avenging steel,</br>For men who form'd in Freedom's sacred cause,</br>Bar'd the red arms of war, and spurn'd the oppressor's laws?

Yes, patriots, yes — behold the land</br>Once press'd by many a sturdy band,</br>By men who shew'd the world, that kings,</br>Oppos'd to men, are puny things!</br>Yes!  view that Britain now combin'd</br>With the worst foes of human kind!</br>Behold her sons, with savage ire</br>Eager to quench fair freedom's fire!</br>And mark her goodly sovereign's pious care</br>Who spreads wide-wasting war, and whets the sword with — prayer.

Shall I, because a poor fork'd thing</br>Whom fate, not merit, made a —,</br>Has dar'd in slav'ry's cause once more</br>To drench the earth with British gore,</br>Shall I, because this scourge would fain</br>Restore to France oppression's chain,</br>Shall I implore the God of peace</br>To grant that slaughter may increase?</br>No — from my soul the war I execrate,</br>And would not join the pray'r t' avoid the felon's fate.

If o'er the murderer's back you fling</br>The purple robe that decks a king,</br>Or 'dizen out a band of thieves</br>In crosiers, mitres, and lawn sleeves</br>You'll find, disguise 'em as you will,</br>That villains will be villains still,</br>So Britons, while your warriors die</br>In the curst cause of tyranny,</br>Howe'er you fast — and pray — and whine — and groan</br>'Tis all an impious cloak, — guilt marks you for her own.</br>
